statements.text: Indo-European languages include Romance languages, Germanic languages and Slavic languages, which share a distant common ancestor.
Romance languages developed from spoken Latin, and many still share similar verb endings and basic vocabulary.
Germanic languages are known for consonant shifts and strong versus weak verbs in their historical development.
Slavic languages often mark grammatical case on nouns, distinguishing roles that Romance languages express with prepositions.
Sino-Tibetan languages commonly use tone and relatively fixed word order instead of heavy case marking.
Afro-Asiatic languages include many Semitic languages, which build related words from shared consonant roots.
Indo-European languages and Afro-Asiatic languages have both spread widely through trade, religion and empire across continents.
Dravidian languages are mainly spoken in South India and differ structurally from neighboring Indo-European languages.
Turkic languages stretch from Turkey to Central Asia, forming a family distinct from Indo-European languages.
Uralic languages, including Finnish and Hungarian, often use long strings of suffixes rather than many separate function words.
Austronesian languages are spread across islands from Madagascar to the Pacific, linked by shared vocabulary and sound patterns.
Language isolates like Basque do not fit neatly into any known family of related languages.
Creole languages often emerge in ports or plantations where speakers of different families, including Indo-European languages, must communicate daily.
Sign languages are full natural languages with their own grammar, unrelated to surrounding spoken Indo-European languages or Sino-Tibetan languages.
Many Romance languages and Germanic languages are written with alphabets originally adapted from scripts used for Semitic languages.
Slavic languages, Turkic languages and Uralic languages have all borrowed vocabulary from nearby Indo-European languages during contact.
Some Germanic languages share word order features with Uralic languages because of long-term contact in Northern Europe.
Romance languages and Slavic languages are often studied together in European universities as branches of Indo-European languages.
Sino-Tibetan languages and Austronesian languages dominate much of Asia and the Pacific, despite belonging to separate families.
Afro-Asiatic languages extend across North Africa and the Middle East, where many Semitic languages play major cultural roles.
Dravidian languages and Indo-European languages coexist in South Asia, leading many speakers to grow up bilingually.
Turkic languages interact with Slavic languages and Indo-European languages in multilingual cities from the Balkans to Central Asia.
Uralic languages and Turkic languages sometimes share grammatical features through contact, despite belonging to distinct language families.
Austronesian languages and Dravidian languages are often compared in typology, though no close genetic relationship is widely accepted.
Language isolates stand apart from Indo-European languages, Afro-Asiatic languages and Sino-Tibetan languages in standard classification charts.
Creole languages typically simplify certain features of Indo-European languages while innovating new, systematic ways to mark tense.
Sign languages can borrow finger-spelled alphabets from Indo-European languages while preserving their own visual grammar.
Romance languages and Germanic languages contribute many loanwords to creole languages in former colonial regions.
Slavic languages sometimes influence creole languages and sign languages through contact in multilingual European or diasporic communities.
Sino-Tibetan languages and sign languages often coexist in cities where Deaf communities build separate linguistic traditions.
Afro-Asiatic languages and Indo-European languages meet around the Mediterranean, encouraging multilingualism and complex patterns of borrowing.
Semitic languages are the best-known branch of Afro-Asiatic languages and influence many neighboring Indo-European languages.
Dravidian languages sometimes adopt loanwords from Indo-European languages, Turkic languages and even Austronesian languages through trade networks.
Turkic languages and Austronesian languages rarely share vocabulary genetically, but modern contact can still produce small sets of loanwords.
Uralic languages stand out in Europe because most surrounding national languages are Indo-European languages of various branches.
Austronesian languages and Indo-European languages both span oceans today, but they reflect very different migration histories.
Language isolates often neighbor Indo-European languages, Afro-Asiatic languages or Uralic languages without showing clear genetic ties.
Creole languages can later influence Indo-European languages in the same region, adding local expressions to standard varieties.
Sign languages and creole languages both demonstrate that human language structure can emerge quickly in new communities.
Romance languages, Germanic languages and Slavic languages share many international scientific terms, often borrowed together from classical sources.
Sino-Tibetan languages and Indo-European languages are frequently compared in typology courses to illustrate differences in word order and morphology.
Afro-Asiatic languages, Dravidian languages and Indo-European languages sometimes show similar patterns purely by chance, not shared ancestry.
Semitic languages, Indo-European languages and Turkic languages all served historically as lingua francas in overlapping trade networks.
Dravidian languages, Uralic languages and language isolates remind linguists that Europe and Asia contain deep, pre-Indo-European histories.
Austronesian languages, Sino-Tibetan languages and Indo-European languages are common options in university programs for comparative historical linguistics.
Creole languages, Austronesian languages and Afro-Asiatic languages can intersect in port cities along Indian Ocean trade routes.
Sign languages, Romance languages and Germanic languages share communities, but Deaf culture maintains distinct norms and linguistic practices.
Romance languages, Sino-Tibetan languages and creole languages are all used online, where new slang spreads quickly across platforms.
Germanic languages, Turkic languages and Uralic languages share certain vowel harmony patterns, though the historical sources of these features differ.
Slavic languages, Afro-Asiatic languages and Austronesian languages rarely intersect geographically, yet comparative studies still highlight interesting typological parallels.
Indo-European languages, Turkic languages and Dravidian languages can all be written in shared scripts, masking their genetic differences.
Sino-Tibetan languages, Uralic languages and language isolates show that Eurasia contains many unrelated linguistic families beyond Indo-European languages.
Semitic languages, Dravidian languages and Uralic languages often appear together in surveys of non-Indo-European languages for students.
Afro-Asiatic languages, Semitic languages and language isolates challenge simple tree diagrams, prompting models with waves and contact zones.
Creole languages, sign languages and language isolates demonstrate that new or unusual categories can be fully expressive and systematic.
Austronesian languages, creole languages and sign languages are increasingly documented, reducing the imbalance favoring major Indo-European languages in grammars.
Sino-Tibetan languages, Afro-Asiatic languages and Turkic languages contribute important data to understanding how word order evolves worldwide.
Romance languages, Dravidian languages and sign languages each show complex agreement systems, expressed through endings, particles or movement patterns.
Germanic languages, Sino-Tibetan languages and creole languages all adapt quickly to technology, coining terms for apps, memes and platforms.
Indo-European languages, Sino-Tibetan languages and sign languages frequently appear together in comparative courses introducing major language categories.
